I think one of the core problems in "normalising" insects as a staple of food is that we're trying to do it from the bottom to the top. We're trying to remove the connotation first by telling people that they should eat insects. And people start advertising their food with insects as the main selling point.

But no, IT'S NOT GONNA HAPPEN. Culture shock doesn't subside overnight. It could last for *years or even decades*. Especially if people feel like you're shoving your entomophagy down their throats. Telling some people to eat insects in a controlled environment such as a studio would be much easier, but I wouldn't say the same for the general audience.

I think, for the general population, it's better for them to NOT realise that what they're eating are in fact, insects. Same with cheese and yoghurts, we eat them since we were young and none of us are the wiser. Only when we grow older we realise that those are basically spoiled milk with molds. But since it's already normal for us to eat them, and everyone seems to eat them in a daily basis, we don't have any problem with those.

Applying that logic to our insect-normalisation campaign, we should just advertise them the same as other protein sources, simply as just a "High-Quality Protein" and whatnot until it has became the norm. And after that it would be optional to just let the masses know that the main ingredients are insects.

Here's a little trivia: some protein shake companies are actually have incorporated crickets as their ingredients for protein. Do the majority of the public aware of that? No. Would they stop consuming the protein shake after they're informed? Possibly no, too.

I was at the end of my rope and just about ready to let her out and deal with the litter when this roommate offered an alternative suggestion to the natural remedy.
She told me that if I gently boinked my kitty with the eraser on the end of a pencil she would go out of heat. I was horrified by the thought at first, but I grew so desperate and the cat was so miserable that I thought I should give it a try, even being as distasteful a task as it was...And my roommate watched with satisfaction as I struggled with the disgusting task.

I love how vegetarian/vegan people think their diet is automatically better. Bullshit. It all comes down to a balanced diet. If I only eat sugar, too many carbs and coconut fat, technically, it is a 'vegan' diet. Is it healthy? Obviously not.

Most of the time vegan people are just more aware of what they are eating because, in order to decide whether to become a vegan, they extensively looked up information, thus making wiser choices nutrition-wise. But that doesn't mean that people who still eat meat did not inform themselves about those issues.
What is definitely the case is that meat (and animal-based) production takes up way more resources and is more environmentally damaging than plant-based production (even though plant-based production is for from being perfect either...). That would be the only convincing argument for me to go vegan. Ethical arguments are too subjective and strongly depend on interpretation. And from a health-related perspective, if you pay attention to what you buy (not buying GMO-hormone-fed, caged cattle, for example), either diet is healthy.

The huge amounts of water the cows drink come in the form of rain that falls from the sky to the ground that then flows into streams and slews.    
And grass, a natural renewable resource is not very nutritious.  That is why it takes so much grass to make a kg of beef.  
So really cows are taking low quality land that is not good for crops and turns it into highly nutritious meat.

This comments section is absolutely spammed with "You are all idiots for not being vegan!" and "eating bugs is dumb!"

Frankly, I love this idea, and I would love to be one of the agricultural engineers that helps make this sort of thing possible.

There are a lot of possibilities. For instance, if you're like me and have Oral Allergy Syndrome, raw fruits and veggies are a no-go. Even many cooked. However, if the plant is digested by insects, and then I eat the insects, the pollen is broken down quite effectively.

Also, the culinary possibilities are awesome as well. We have several staple meats, like pork, chicken, and beef, which each have different properties and tastes. But imagine THOUSANDS of meats with different flavors and purposes. And I wonder, if I had my crickets eat parsley or something, would this alter their flavor?

And here's another thing. People are freaked out at eating bugs because of "all the legs" or whatever. Umm, we don't normally eat pork, chicken, or beef when it's fully-intact. Same with fish. Eastern dishes freak out western people because it is "staring at them". So I mean, eating crickets could be in the form of a cooked, ground, and recooked meats, like "cricket burgers". Or meal worms could be ground, mixed with other ingredients and puffed to make a snack like pork rinds or puffcorn. Or how about that meal worm flour in the video?

Frankly, I think people need to get over themselves. Little kids freak out like this when they discover "beef is made from moo cows?!"

As someone who has eaten insects multiple time in the past, I can assure everyone that it is definitely a great alternative to meat. Notably crickets and grasshoppers are tasty, even with only a bit of seasoning. The flavour of them can be best described as nutty and crunchy, the latter depending on the kind of insect. Now, before you run to the trash bin to throw up, nobody expects you to eat living insects or something, so get that thought out of your head. It was pretty easy for me to get over the fear factor insects generally create for humans. 

The only problem however (as mentioned a few times before in the comments) is finding a good supplier of insects. In most western countries, they are rather difficult to acquire, and pricy too, simply because it is not exactly a booming business. Thankfully, if people start to accept it and try it more, this issue will probably be resolved quickly (In Cambodia, a pound of insects was as cheap as a package of gum, lol).

The important thing to understand is that as protein is essential, it is found in virtually every vegan meal. Meat is not, never will be and never has been a "vital" food. It is an addicting practice that only serves to cause mild retardation in human physiology and in microscopic levels. Likewise yoghurt is also not nutritious, it contains galactose, caso-morphins (basically morphine), casein (the main protein, which is barely digestible and causes rapid growth of abnormalities-> cancer), the calcium is barely absorbed. since it is not conveniently in trapped in a leaf, we piss out most of it. To deal with the dropped ph levels in the stomach, the human body needs calcium to neutralize the casein digestion. But milk contains calcium, so it's a win-win, right? It turns out that humans are laughably incompetent at digesting calcium from milk. In the long run, consuming a lot of these substances causes considerably higher ph and calcium deficiency. This is not exclusive to milk. Digesting meat and high amounts of animal protein causes more damage, because of the steady decline in calcium and inefficiency to digest animal cells.
High amounts of protein are even hurtful, vegan or omnivore. A high amount of protein even as vegans also causes a more prominent risk for disease because of the lower ph (even though a vegan diet causes considerably lower risks)

Furthermore, there is a grave misconception of what exactly humans/cro-magnons/homo-sapiens have evolved to digest most efficiently. It is not meat, if it was then there wouldn't be countries filled with fat people, in other words, we would have developed more efficient fat digestion. But the human ability for fat digestion is laughable, and poor at most. The staple for human food is starch (rice, potato,corn, all kinds of grains and lentils) and fruit and vegetables on top of that, with the addition of nuts and seeds. The complex carbohydrate, starch, is by far the best fuel for humans.

This video lies about the water requirements/kg of chicken and cows.  If we look at a KFC chicken it is alive for 7 weeks tops, and will weigh about 3lbs (1.3kg).  According to http://www.omafra.gov.on.ca/english/engineer/facts/07-023.htm a chicken needs at most 0.26L water per day for first 4 weeks of life, and 0.45L/day at MOST for the rest of their life. So a 3lb chicken will need 16.73L of water TOTAL, this equals less than 12.9L water/kg of chicken.
